147.text: Now, sunlight, of course, comes into this.

150.text: And vitamin D has had a great deal of press,

152.text: and a lot of people get concerned about it.

154.text: And we need vitamin D. It's now a requirement that children have a certain amount.

158.text: My grandmother grew up in Glasgow,

161.text: back in the 1920s and '30s when rickets was a real problem

164.text: and cod liver oil was brought in.

166.text: And that really prevented the rickets that used to be common in this city.

170.text: And I as a child was fed cod liver oil by my grandmother.

174.text: I distinctly -- nobody forgets cod liver oil.

177.text: But an association: The higher people's blood levels of vitamin D are,

182.text: the less heart disease they have, the less cancer.

185.text: There seems to be a lot of data suggesting that vitamin D is very good for you.

189.text: And it is, to prevent rickets and so on.

191.text: But if you give people vitamin D supplements,

194.text: you don't change that high rate of heart disease.

198.text: And the evidence for it preventing cancers is not yet great.

201.text: So what I'm going to suggest is that vitamin D is not the only story in town.

206.text: It's not the only reason preventing heart disease.

210.text: High vitamin D levels, I think, are a marker for sunlight exposure,

220.text: Anyway, I came back from Australia,

222.text: and despite the obvious risks to my health, I moved to Aberdeen.

228.text: Now, in Aberdeen, I started my dermatology training.

231.text: But I also became interested in research,

233.text: and in particular I became interested in this substance, nitric oxide.

236.text: Now these three guys up here,

239.text: won the Nobel Prize for medicine back in 1998.

242.text: And they were the first people to describe

244.text: this new chemical transmitter, nitric oxide.

248.text: What nitric oxide does is it dilates blood vessels,

251.text: so it lowers your blood pressure.

252.text: It also dilates the coronary arteries, so it stops angina.

257.text: And what was remarkable about it

258.text: was in the past when we think of chemical messengers within the body,

262.text: we thought of complicated things like estrogen and insulin,

267.text: Very complex processes with very complex chemicals

270.text: that fit into very complex receptors.

272.text: And here's this incredibly simple molecule,

275.text: a nitrogen and an oxygen that are stuck together,

278.text: and yet these are hugely important for [unclear] our low blood pressure,

283.text: for neurotransmission, for many, many things,

289.text: And I started doing research, and we found, very excitingly,

292.text: that the skin produces nitric oxide.

295.text: So it's not just in the cardiovascular system it arises.

299.text: Well, having found that and published that,

301.text: I thought, well, what's it doing?

303.text: How do you have low blood pressure in your skin?

305.text: It's not the heart. What do you do?

307.text: So I went off to the States, as many people do if they're going to do research,

311.text: and I spent a few years in Pittsburgh. This is Pittsburgh.

315.text: And I was interested in these really complex systems.

317.text: We thought that maybe nitric oxide affected cell death,

321.text: and how cells survive, and their resistance to other things.

324.text: And I first off started work in cell culture, growing cells,

327.text: and then I was using knockout mouse models --

329.text: mice that couldn't make the gene.

331.text: We worked out a mechanism, which -- NO was helping cells survive.

335.text: And I then moved back to Edinburgh.

339.text: And in Edinburgh, the experimental animal we use is the medical student.

342.text: It's a species close to human,

346.text: They're free, you don't shave them, they feed themselves,

349.text: and nobody pickets your office saying,

354.text: So they're really an ideal model.

359.text: was that we couldn't reproduce in man the data we had shown in mice.

364.text: It seemed we couldn't turn off the production

367.text: of nitric oxide in the skin of humans.

370.text: We put on creams that blocked the enzyme that made it,

373.text: we injected things. We couldn't turn off the nitric oxide.

377.text: And the reason for this, it turned out, after two or three years' work,

380.text: was that in the skin we have huge stores

385.text: not of nitric oxide, because nitric oxide is a gas,

388.text: and it's released -- (Poof!) -- and in a few seconds it's away,

391.text: but it can be turned into these forms of nitric oxide --

399.text: and your skin has got really large stores of NO.

403.text: And we then thought to ourselves, with those big stores,

406.text: I wonder if sunlight might activate those stores

409.text: and release them from the skin,

411.text: where the stores are about 10 times as big as what's in the circulation.

414.text: Could the sun activate those stores into the circulation,

417.text: and there in the circulation do its good things for your cardiovascular system?

425.text: so what we did was we thought

426.text: we'd have to expose our experimental animals to sunlight.

430.text: And so what we did was we took a bunch of volunteers

434.text: and we exposed them to ultraviolet light.

437.text: So these are kind of sunlamps.

438.text: Now, what we were careful to do was,

441.text: vitamin D is made by ultraviolet B rays

444.text: and we wanted to separate our story from the vitamin D story.

448.text: So we used ultraviolet A, which doesn't make vitamin D.

452.text: When we put people under a lamp

454.text: for the equivalent of about 30 minutes of sunshine in summer in Edinburgh,

459.text: what we produced was, we produced a rise

464.text: So we put patients with these subjects under the UV,

467.text: and their NO levels do go up,

469.text: and their blood pressure goes down.

471.text: Not by much, as an individual level,

474.text: but enough at a population level

476.text: to shift the rates of heart disease in a whole population.

480.text: And when we shone UV at them,

482.text: or when we warmed them up to the same level as the lamps,

486.text: but didn't actually let the rays hit the skin, this didn't happen.

489.text: So this seems to be a feature of ultraviolet rays hitting the skin.

496.text: This appeared to be more marked in older people.

499.text: I'm not sure exactly how much.

501.text: One of the subjects here was my mother-in-law,

503.text: and clearly I do not know her age.

506.text: But certainly in people older than my wife,

509.text: this appears to be a more marked effect.

512.text: And the other thing I should mention

513.text: was there was no change in vitamin D.

516.text: This is separate from vitamin D.

518.text: So vitamin D is good for you -- it stops rickets,

519.text: it prevents calcium metabolism, important stuff.

521.text: But this is a separate mechanism from vitamin D.

524.text: Now, one of the problems with looking at blood pressure

527.text: is your body does everything it can

529.text: to keep your blood pressure at the same place.

530.text: If your leg is chopped off and you lose blood,

532.text: your body will clamp down, increase the heart rate,

535.text: do everything it can to keep your blood pressure up.

537.text: That is an absolutely fundamental physiological principle.

542.text: is we've moved on to looking at blood vessel dilatation.

545.text: So we've measured -- this is again,

547.text: notice no tail and hairless, this is a medical student.

552.text: In the arm, you can measure blood flow in the arm

555.text: by how much it swells up as some blood flows into it.

558.text: And what we've shown is that doing a sham irradiation --

562.text: this is the thick line here --

563.text: this is shining UV on the arm so it warms up

565.text: but keeping it covered so the rays don't hit the skin.

568.text: There is no change in blood flow, in dilatation of the blood vessels.

574.text: during the UV and for an hour after it,

577.text: there is dilation of the blood vessels.

579.text: This is the mechanism by which you lower blood pressure,

582.text: by which you dilate the coronary arteries also,

584.text: to let the blood be supplied with the heart.

586.text: So here, further data that ultraviolet -- that's sunlight --

591.text: has benefits on the blood flow and the cardiovascular system.

595.text: So we thought we'd just kind of model --

598.text: Different amounts of UV hit different parts of the Earth at different times of year,

604.text: so you can actually work out those stores of nitric oxide --

608.text: the nitrates, nitrites, nitrosothiols in the skin --

613.text: Different wavelengths of light have different activities of doing that.

617.text: So you can look at the wavelengths of light that do that.

619.text: And you can look -- So, if you live on the equator, the sun comes straight overhead,

623.text: it comes through a very thin bit of atmosphere.

625.text: In winter or summer, it's the same amount of light.

627.text: If you live up here, in summer

630.text: the sun is coming fairly directly down,

632.text: but in winter it's coming through a huge amount of atmosphere,

636.text: and much of the ultraviolet is weeded out,

639.text: and the range of wavelengths that hit the Earth

641.text: are different from summer to winter.

644.text: So what you can do is you can multiply those data

648.text: and you can calculate how much nitric oxide

651.text: would be released from the skin into the circulation.

654.text: Now, if you're on the equator here --

656.text: that's these two lines here, the red line and the purple line --

659.text: the amount of nitric oxide that's released is the area under the curve,

664.text: it's the area in this space here.

666.text: So if you're on the equator, December or June,

668.text: you've got masses of NO being released from the skin.

672.text: So Ventura is in southern California.

674.text: In summer, you might as well be at the equator.

676.text: It's great. Lots of NO is released.

678.text: Ventura mid-winter, well, there's still a decent amount.

682.text: Edinburgh in summer, the area beneath the curve is pretty good,

686.text: but Edinburgh in winter, the amount of NO that can be released

691.text: is next to nothing, tiny amounts.

696.text: We're still working at this story,

698.text: we're still developing it, we're still expanding it.

701.text: We think it probably accounts for a lot of the north-south health divide within Britain,

708.text: well, we know that the skin has got very large stores

711.text: of nitric oxide as these various other forms.

713.text: We suspect a lot of these come from diet,

718.text: has a lot of these nitric oxides that we think go to the skin.

721.text: We think they're then stored in the skin,

723.text: and we think the sunlight releases this

725.text: where it has generally beneficial effects.

728.text: And this is ongoing work, but dermatologists --

732.text: My day job is saying to people, "You've got skin cancer,

735.text: it's caused by sunlight, don't go in the sun."

737.text: I actually think a far more important message

739.text: is that there are benefits as well as risks to sunlight.

743.text: Yes, sunlight is the major alterable risk factor for skin cancer,

749.text: but deaths from heart disease are a hundred times higher

753.text: And I think that we need to be more aware of,

756.text: and we need to find the risk-benefit ratio.

760.text: and how can we finesse this best for our general health?

764.text: So, thank you very much indeed.
